parameters.definition: Time to prepare one in-vivo experiment
Time to execute one in-vivo experiment
Time to prepare one ex-vivo experiment
Time to execute one ex-vivo experiment
Radiation units received from one in-vivo experiment
Radiation units received from one ex-vivo experiment
Maximum time allowed for preparing the experiments
Maximum time allowed for executing the experiments

description: A researcher must perform two types of experiments, in-vivo and ex-vivo. In-vivo experiments require \param{TimeInVivoPrep} minutes to prepare and \param{TimeInVivoExec} minutes to execute. Ex-vivo experiments require \param{TimeExVivoPrep} minutes to prepare and \param{TimeExVivoExec} minutes to execute. In addition, in-vivo experiments give the researcher \param{RadiationInVivo} units of radiation while ex-vivo experiments give the researcher \param{RadiationExVivo} units of radiation. At most \param{MaxTimePrep} minutes can be used for preparation and \param{MaxTimeExec} minutes for execution of the experiments. How many of each experiment should be scheduled by the researcher to minimize the total radiation received by the researcher?
